newsitem.title: GERMANY: Bankgesellschaft says not in takeover talks.
newsitem.headline: Bankgesellschaft says not in takeover talks.

text.p: Germany's Bankgesellschaft Berlin AG which is believed to be interested in acquiring BHF-Bank AG, said on Monday it was interested in acquisitions to strengthen its business but added that it was not in takeover talks at present.
A spokeswoman for Bankgesellschaft said the bank was thinking about which business areas could be strengthened through acquisitions and that several banks in Germany and Europe were possible targets.
"The impression that everything is focused on BHF-Bank is wrong," the spokeswoman said in response to a Reuter enquiry.
She added that negotiations about a merger with Norddeutsche Landesbank (NordLB) took precedence at present, with the main issue being the valuations of the two banks.
Berliner Zeitung reported on Saturday that Bankgesellschaft had identified Frankfurt-based BHF-Bank as an institution whose business would complement its own activities.

BHF-Bank's shares had surged on Friday following a report in Boersen-Zeitung that Bankgesellschaft was interested in buying a stake of at least 75 percent in it. German markets are closed on Monday for the Pentecost public holiday.
Both banks have denied they are in talks and major shareholders in BHF also said they did not plan to sell their stakes.

However, Bankgesellschaft chief executive Wolfgang Rupf was quoted in Saturday's edition of Boersen-Zeitung as saying BHF was one of several banks that had been discussed by Bankgesellschaft's management board.
BfG Bank, a subsidiary of Credit Lyonnais, had also been discussed, Rupf was quoted as saying.
BHF's asset management unit Frankfurt Trust would be an "interesting addition" to Bankgesellschaft although it would unrealistic just to buy the bank's fund arm, Rupf added.

Asked if Berlin-based Bankgesellschaft was interested in buying BHF because it wanted to strengthen its position in the Frankfurt financial market, Rupf said, "We have to expand our activities in Frankfurt in any case."
